name: Identity and Access Management (IAM)
description: Think of IAM as the bouncer for your cloud environment—it controls who gets in and what they're allowed to do once they're inside. Your Journal API already uses authentication (thanks to Phase 3), but now we need to make sure the cloud infrastructure around it is locked down too. Let's dig into how IAM works across cloud providers.

learning_steps.description: Start with your cloud provider's IAM docs. Don't try to memorize everything—focus on understanding the core model (users, roles, policies) and how permissions flow.
These videos walk through real IAM setups. Pick the one for your cloud provider and follow along—pause and try things in your own account as you go.
learning_steps.title: IAM in Action

learning_steps.description: These are the industry-standard guides that security teams actually reference. Skim them now to get the big picture—you'll come back to them when you're hardening your Journal API in the capstone.

Every cloud provider uses the same core concepts, just with slightly different names:

- **Users** — Individual people or apps that need access
- **Groups** — Collections of users who need the same permissions (e.g., "developers")
- **Roles** — A set of permissions that can be assumed temporarily (this is how your Journal API should access cloud resources)
- **Policies** — The actual rules that say "this identity can do X on resource Y"
learning_steps.title: IAM Components

learning_steps.description: This is probably the most important security concept you'll learn: give users and services only the bare minimum permissions they need. If your Journal API only reads and writes to a database, it shouldn't have permission to delete your entire cloud account. If credentials get compromised, least privilege limits the blast radius.

Here's a key distinction you'll use with your Journal API:

- **User accounts** are for people—you, your teammates, your admin
- **Service accounts** are for applications—your API, your CI/CD pipeline, your monitoring tools

Your Journal API should never run with your personal credentials. It gets its own service account with just the permissions it needs.

You already used these concepts in Phase 3 when you added auth to your Journal API, but let's make sure the distinction is crystal clear:

- **Authentication (AuthN)** — "Who are you?" (logging in, MFA, API keys)
- **Authorization (AuthZ)** — "What are you allowed to do?" (permissions, policies, roles)

You can be authenticated (logged in) but not authorized (not allowed to delete things).
Time to get your hands dirty. Pick the workshop for your cloud provider and actually do it—reading about IAM is one thing, but configuring it yourself is where the learning really happens.
Want to see what happens when IAM goes wrong? These labs let you practice attacking misconfigured IAM setups—it's the best way to understand why proper configuration matters.
